items.title: How Photoshop uses browser tech to the limits
items.content:
üöÄ Frontend Focus

#‚Äã612 ‚Äî October 4, 2023 | Read on the web

The Ultimate Low-Quality Image Placeholder Technique ‚Äî Harry notes the importance in offering a reasonably pleasant experience for users who find themselves waiting for images to load, explaining how Low-Quality Image Placeholders (LQIP) are one such possible answer. The problem however is they don‚Äôt particularly play nice with Core Web Vitals and Largest Contentful Paint (LCP). This post goes into any nuances to be aware of, along with how best to implement a¬†solution.

Harry Roberts

How Photoshop is Now on the Web ‚Äî Getting Photoshop onto the Web (where it has been for a little while now ‚Äì we first covered Photoshop's journey to the Web in 2021) was the result of both a lot of collaboration and a myriad of modern browser technologies (WebAssembly, Web Components + Lit, Service Workers & more) that Addy covers in this¬†post.

Addy Osmani

Feel the Power of More Than 420,000 Teammates and Work #LikeABosch ‚Äî At Bosch, we shape the future with high-quality technologies and services to inspire people and improve their lives. And it‚Äôs our people who make us remarkable. Our success is your success. Let‚Äôs celebrate together. Learn¬†more.

Bosch sponsor

Flexbox Froggy: A Game for Learning CSS Flexbox ‚Äî We first linked this eight years ago but this is still a neat introduction to flexible box layout which is now, at least, supported by basically every visual browser¬†going.

Codepip

Chrome Now Shows Each Active Tab‚Äôs Memory Usage ‚Äî Chrome Canary has neat new hover cards that show the memory usage for each open¬†tab.

Addy Osmani

‚ö°Ô∏è IN BRIEF

  • Satya Nadella isn't thrilled about Google's defeault search deals.

  • The CSS directionality :dir() pseudo-class is set to ship in Chrome 120. Here's the spec.

  • Seth Dobbs is the next CEO of W3C.

  • AR One Sans is a new font on Google Fonts designed for AR environments.

  • Vivaldi now has a browser on iOS. WebKit-powered,¬†too.

  • Search engine DuckDuckGo has celebrated its 15th birthday.

üìô Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Get Ready for Interop 2024 ‚Äî What you need to know about the cross-browser effort so far, what the plan is for Interop 2024, and how you can contribute to what‚Äôs included for next¬†year.

Jen Simmons (WebKit)

‚ñ∂¬†¬†What‚Äôs New in DevTools - Chrome 118 ‚Äî Jecelyn Yeen runs through the DevTools updates we can now find in Chrome 118, including the ability inspect the CSS @ property in the Styles pane, being able to emulate prefers-reduced-transparency and¬†more.

Chrome for Developers

Product For Engineers: A Newsletter Helping Flex Your Product¬†Muscle ‚Äî Subscribe to get curated advice on building great products, lessons from PostHog, and best practices of top¬†startups.

Posthog sponsor

Upgrading Frontend Dependencies with Confidence ‚Äî Tests can provide a way to see if our app logic isn‚Äôt working the way we expect, but what if a frontend component is rendering incorrectly? We can turn to visual regression testing. S√©bastien, known for his work on Docusaurus, shares a workflow based on GitHub Actions, Playwright, and Argos that's suitable for this¬†task.

S√©bastien Lorber

From WebGL to WebGPU ‚Äî Some tips for WebGL developers who are migrating to¬†WebGPU.

Fran√ßois Beaufort

Fran√ßois Beaufort also shares what's new in WebGPU for Chrome 118.

Using The Intl Segmenter API ‚Äî Kilian shared on Twitter that he lost some time ‚Äútrying to detect words in non-western language strings‚Äù but then learnt about the Intl.segmenter browser API. It has a ton of functionality for editing and formatting of text and numbers. This post shows us how to use¬†it.

Kilian Valkhof

Animating Multi-Page Navigations with Browser View Transitions and Astro ‚Äî A beginner-friendly guide, with demos and code, that walks you through the use of the Browser View Transitions API paired with Astro for a smoother navigation¬†experience.

Igor Penaque

Misconceptions Can Kill Accessibility Momentum ‚Äî Reflecting on accessibility misconceptions and how new standards and technologies can inadvertently add to¬†them.

Eric Eggert

Making a Website is for Everyone ‚Äî ‚ÄúThe web‚Äôs low barrier to entry led me to a career that has been a boon for my life. I hope it can do the same for¬†others.‚Äù

Jim Nielsen

Websites in the Dock ‚Äî Did you know you can now launch web apps as standalone apps in (the newest version of)¬†macOS?

Jeremy Keith

The Angular Renaissance: Why Frontend Devs Should Revisit It
Loraine Lawson (The New Stack)

üîß Code, Tools & Resources

Viselect: Let Users Visually Select DOM Elements ‚Äî If you‚Äôve got a variety of elements and you want users to be able to select them in groups, individually, or even in multiple groups, this lets you offer that functionality easily. Can be used in a vanilla fashion or with integrations for React or¬†Vue.js.

Simon Reinisch

Critical 6.0: Extracts and Inlines Critical Path CSS from HTML ‚Äî A Node powered tool for when you want to optimize a page‚Äôs rendering to the max by inlining above-the-fold¬†CSS.

Addy Osmani

Add Figma Like Collaborative Features in a Few Lines of Code ‚Äî Create collaborative features, from live cursors to avatar stacks with Spaces, our in-app collaboration¬†SDK.

Ably sponsor

blog-cells: Add Runnable, Interactive Code Snippets on¬†Pages ‚Äî Like embedding a JSFiddle or Codepen, but these are a cleaner and minimal solution that work well in tutorials and in SSGs like Jekyll or Hugo. Try some examples¬†here.

Varun Ramesh

MiniSim: A Native Mac Menubar App for Launching iOS and Android Emulators ‚Äî It‚Äôs open source, includes various configuration settings for a handy mobile testing¬†solution.

Oskar Kwa≈õniewski

Sprite Your SVGs: Paste SVG Code to Generate an Optimized¬†Sprite ‚Äî CSS sprites aren‚Äôt so much of a thing nowadays, but if you have a use case for an SVG sprite, this helps with the code¬†generation.

Jos√© Donato

Atrament.js: A Library for Smooth Drawing on HTML Canvas ‚Äî Demo.
Jakub Fiala

items.title: What do you think about HTML in 2023?
items.content:
üöÄ Frontend Focus

#‚Äã611 ‚Äî September 27, 2023 | Read on the web

Take the State of HTML 2023 Survey (and Change the¬†Web) ‚Äî A new survey from the folks behind State of JavaScript and State of CSS. This is a natural companion to the other two surveys and should result in a more complete overview of the web platform as a whole. We encourage everyone to fill it out as answers submitted by October 1 will be used to inform this year's Interop 2024 proposals. Lea Verou outlines how this survey came to be and what you need to know. We'll share the results too, in due¬†course.

Devographics

Cloudflare Fonts: Enhancing Web Font Privacy and Speed ‚Äî A new one-click service coming to Cloudflare users that means sites using Google Fonts will be able to load the fonts from their own domain rather than from¬†Google and reduce the number of round trips from eight to¬†one.

Bullock and Woodhead (Cloudflare)

CSS Foundations with Emma Bostian ‚Äî This extensive video course will help you nail the CSS essentials. You'll learn core terminology, practical skills (such as Flexbox and Grid), and gain hands-on experience ‚Äî all of which will equip you with the fundamentals required for creating professional responsive¬†sites.

Frontend Masters sponsor

The Path to Awesome CSS Easing with linear() ‚Äî The new CSS linear() easing function is on the horizon, expanding what we can do when it comes to creating more natural-feeling animations and transitions. This post looks at what the current state of CSS easing is and demonstrates what we can expect from linear() once it¬†lands.

Jhey Tompkins

Why HTTP/3 is Eating the World ‚Äî What problems HTTP/3 solves, how it performs, why it‚Äôs seen such swift adoption, and what limitations it's still working to¬†overcome.

Robin Marx

‚ö°Ô∏è IN BRIEF

  • Today‚Äôs Google Doodle celebrates 25 years of the search giant.

  • Firefox 118 is out now and includes automated translation of web content. The general release notes are here, with the developer information here.

  • ‚ñ∂Ô∏è A video outlining what's new in version 1.38 of web testing and automation framework Playwright.

  • Ben Hawkes goes deep into a significant WebP related security vulnerability that could allow out of bounds memory writes via a specially crafted HTML page. More discussion¬†here.

üìô Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

The Design System Ecosystem ‚Äî This post goes deep into the weeds on a ‚Äòlayer-cake approach‚Äô to creating robust, mature design systems. Of course, the advice isn‚Äôt one size fits all, but there‚Äôs plenty of good takeaways¬†here.

Brad Frost

Responsive Type Scales with Composable CSS Utilities ‚Äî With the help of calc(), clamp() and CSS vars, we can create composable, responsive, and fluid type scales that smoothly adapts to viewport and container¬†widths.

Tobias Ahlin Bjerrome

Debugging Errors Faster with Distributed Tracing ‚Äî Join us October 17, to learn how distributed tracing helps uncover elusive bugs & performance problems in¬†microservices.

Sentry sponsor

'Web Push Is Almost Usable with iOS 17' ‚Äî ‚Äúwith enough dedication and grit, you can get push notifications to show up on iOS devices, and it‚Äôs a little easier with iOS¬†17‚Äù

Matt Steele

‚ñ∂¬†¬†CSS Terminology Demystified ‚Äî A 5 minute video to help you talk more confidently about CSS terminology, such as declarations, statements, etc.

Zoran Jambor beginner

Your Cache Headers Could Probably be More Aggressive ‚Äî A look at what we can do to push cache performance (for some assets) even¬†further.

Alex MacArthur

‚ñ∂¬†¬†Accessibility Is Easy ‚Ä¶ Except for When It Isn‚Äôt ‚Äî A half-hour look at how to approach making complicated UIs accessible using standard techniques and a ‚Äúlittle more creative¬†thinking‚Äù.

Ian Lloyd

Solved by CSS Scroll-Driven Animations: Detect if an Element Can Scroll or Not
Bramus Van Damme

What Can You Do with data- Attributes?
Chris Ferdinandi

üßë‚Äçüíª JOBS

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired ‚Äî Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profile¬†now.
Hired

üîß Code, Tools & Resources

ChatGPT.js: A JavaScript Library for Working with ChatGPT's¬†DOM ‚Äî Includes a fairly extensive API that lets you interact with ChatGPT for use in Chrome extensions, Tampermonkey scripts, and so¬†on. Take note of the rather in-your-face design of this page - wow!¬†üòÖ

KudoAI

Mimic.css: A CSS Animation Library of Unique Animations ‚Äî Not a new project but we can almost guarantee these are animations you haven‚Äôt seen before! Examples here, where you can try out lawn mower, candle in the wind, drop it like it‚Äôs hot, and¬†more.

Eric Treacy

Repo Trends: View and Analyze Trends in GitHub Repository Issues Over Time ‚Äî A nicely designed tool that displays visual data for open issues and pull requests on a given GitHub¬†repository.

Steve Sanders

Media-Card-Web-Component: A Web Component to Fetch Details on Books, Movies, Music, etc. ‚Äî This will tap into various third-party APIs for Open Library, iTunes, The Movie Database, and so on, to display media and info for the requested item. Examples¬†here.

Marketing Pipeline

little-rat: A Chrome Extension to Monitor (and Optionally Block) Other Extensions' Network Calls

Daniel Nakov

Swup: A Flexible Page Transition Library for Server-Side Rendered Sites ‚Äî A library that benefits hugely from checking out the demos. v4.4 adds experimental ViewTransition support.

Georgy Marchuk

üï∞ ICYMI (Some older stuff that's still worth checking out)

  • Dipika Bhattacharya explains how the CSS :not() pseudo-class behaves when multiple selectors are passed as an argument.

  • Ben Edelstein highlights an industrial supply website that you likely haven't heard of, and what smart design choices it makes. We love it.

  • SVG symbols allow you to declare an SVG element once per page and reuse it many times without losing web performance. Bart Stefanski looks at whether they actually significantly boost speed or not.

  • Dave Rupert shares how to get started with View Transitions on multi-page¬†apps.

Ipx.

items.title: Safari 17 is here
items.content:
üëã Hello! This week we've asked Ahmad Shadeed to share a few of his favorite frontend tools. Be sure to scroll down and see them.
__
Chris Brandrick, Editor

üöÄ Frontend Focus

#‚Äã610 ‚Äî September 20, 2023 | Read on the web

WebKit Features in Safari 17.0 ‚Äî Safari 17.0 is now available for both iOS 17 and iPadOS 17, it will arrive on macOS a little later this month. This release is packed, and includes support for the <search> element, the popover attribute, the CSS font-size-adjust property, the Storage API, JPEG XL, and much more. Big¬†release!

Jen Simmons and the WebKit team

v0: Using AI to Build Frontend Components? ‚Äî An interesting experiment from Vercel where you submit prompts like ‚Äúa country selection field‚Äù or ‚Äúa contact form‚Äù and it returns copy/paste-able shadcn/ui + Tailwind CSS code. It‚Äôs in ‚Äúprivate alpha‚Äù for now, but you can take a good look at how it works¬†here. A sign of the¬†future?

Vercel Labs

The Complete UI Component Library For Enterprise Web Apps ‚Äî A professional UI component library with power widgets like data grid, calendar, scheduler & Gantt charts. Includes API docs, guides and an unreasonable amount of demos to play with. Seamlessly integrates with React, Angular, Vue & Salesforce¬†apps.

Bryntum sponsor

free-for.dev: A Bumper List of Stuff That's 'Free' for Developers ‚Äî An interesting and extensive list of hosted services or otherwise paid-for products that have free tiers or options for developers. We linked to this a couple of years ago but it has been updated a lot¬†since.

R.I.Pienaar

A (More) Modern CSS Reset ‚Äî Andy created a modern CSS reset almost four years ago, but it‚Äôs time for an update to, well, keep it¬†modern.

Andy Bell

‚ö°Ô∏è IN BRIEF

  • WordPress blogs can now be followed in the fediverse.

  • üìÖ CodeWord is an upcoming free online event (tomorrow) looking at how developers interact with content in their code. Speakers include Chris Coyier, Cassisy Williams, Miriam Schwab, and others.

  • Browser company Vivaldi has penned an open letter to the EU Commission to express "concerns over Microsoft‚Äôs anti-competitive practices" in regards to Edge.

  • Figma-friendly design tool Anima now has Tailwind CSS support.

  • ‚ôñ Opera is releasing a 'special edition' of their browser, with built-in..¬†chess?

üìô Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Get All That Network Activity Under Control with Priority Hints ‚Äî Alex notes how the browser is pretty good at prioritizing resources requests on its own, but it‚Äôs not perfect. He shows us how priority hints makes it easy to provide explicit instructions, and just what scenarios they‚Äôre most helpful¬†in.

Alex MacArthur

More CSS Findings from the Threads App ‚Äî Ahmad continues his spelunking into Meta‚Äôs new social network, revealing a few interesting CSS findings from the Threads web¬†app.

Ahmad Shadeed

How to Adjust Image Size Without Distortion | AI-Powered Smart Resize ‚Äî This feature allows you to automate image resizing without losing quality or distorting objects in a¬†picture.

Uploadcare sponsor

Revealing Images¬†with¬†CSS Mask¬†Animations ‚Äî A look at combining various CSS masks to create fancy image hover transitions/reveals. There's lots of visual demos and code¬†examples here.

Temani Afif

A Beginner‚Äôs Guide to Using Pico CSS ‚Äî An overview of getting started with this slimline¬†framework.

David Uzondu

items.title: Being lazy in the right places
items.content:
üëã Hey! This week we've asked Chris Coyier to share a few of his favorite tools and services. Be sure to scroll down and check them¬†out.
__
Chris Brandrick, Editor

üöÄ Frontend Focus

#‚Äã609 ‚Äî September 13, 2023 | Read on the web

Stop Lazy Loading Product and Hero Images ‚Äî Jason highlights a performance issue seen on many ecommerce sites around lazy loading usage, particularly its overuse: ‚ÄúLazy loading is a key technique when it comes to increasing page performance, but like any technique, it shouldn‚Äôt be applied¬†everywhere‚Äù.

Jason Grigsby

üí¨ Related: Terence Eden recently blogged that he "kind of hates" lazy loading due to it having what he calls "a pretty horrible failure mode" in situations where a user might drop¬†offline.

How to Create Custom Cross-Form Control Validator in Angular ‚Äî See step-by-step how to create a custom validator in a reactive Angular form with a login screen that requires a confirmation password to match the original¬†password.

Kendo UI for Angular sponsor

W3C Introduces Web Sustainability Guidelines ‚Äî From the Sustainable Web Design Community Group comes a set of guidelines on Sustainable Web Design, explaining how to design and build ‚Äúdigital products and services that put people and the planet first‚Äù. You can read the draft¬†here.

W3C

Web Components Accessibility FAQ ‚Äî Manuel runs through the most important questions regarding web component accessibility, including dependencies, shadow DOM queries, custom elements, and¬†more.

Manuel Matuzoviƒá

‚ö°Ô∏è IN BRIEF

  • What were the "no-no's" of web design in 1999? Jakob Nielsen shared what he deemed the top ten mistakes you could make from a usability perspective. Helpful insights that still mostly stand up¬†today.

  • WOFF may have left the building as a web font format, but long live¬†WOFF2!

  • WordPress has an interesting new 100-year plan to help you secure your 'online legacy for a lifetime'. It's not cheap.

  • Chrome is getting a bit of a new look based on Google's 'Material You' design language.

  • Version 15 of developer browser Polypane is out, running on Chromium 116, with a new browser panel, performance improvements, and more.

üíõ ¬†Memories of Molly ‚Äî Last week we shared the sad news that Molly Holzschlag passed away, here Eric Meyer reflects on her memory. Others in the web community have also shared their thoughts on Molly, including words from Jay Hoffmann, Bruce Lawson, Aaron Gustafson, and Deborah¬†Edwards-O√±oro.

Eric Meyer

üìô Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

How to Make Charts and Graphs More Accessible ‚Äî Some solid pointers on how to make your visual data accessible and more¬†usable.

Whitney Lewis

Creating Custom Easing Effects in CSS Animations with¬†linear() ‚Äî This CSS timing function enables custom easing in animations. Here‚Äôs a look at how it works compared with other timing functions used for easing, along with practical¬†examples.

Michelle Barker

Frontend Performance Monitoring 101 ‚Äî Learn the basics of Frontend application performance monitoring to see (and fix) slow faster. Join us for a live¬†AMA.

Sentry sponsor

The New Google Fonts: Finding What You‚Äôre Looking for ‚Äî The Google Fonts website has had a redesign, with new search and filter¬†options.

Tobias Kunisch (Google)

‚ñ∂Ô∏è ¬†A Screen Reader User‚Äôs 'Weird Tricks' to Make Accessible Sites
Bruce Lawson

A New Method to Validate URLs in JavaScript
Stefan Judis

HTML5 Template: A Base Starter HTML Boilerplate for Any Project
Louis Lazaris

üîé FIVE IN FOCUS with Chris Coyier

Five recommendations from Chris Coyier, co-founder of popular social development environment CodePen, and co-host of the ShopTalk podcast.

  1. CleanShot X
    Really great macOS-specific screenshot & screencast recording tool. This is a somewhat crowded market, but the feature set and polish of CleanShot X makes it a clear standout to me. I use it a dozen times a day I bet. I like that it comes in Setapp, because it helps make that subscription a no-brainer to me. Setapp has other indispensable tools for me, like TablePlus, Paste, BusyCal, and Sip.
  2. Feedbin
    The finest RSS reader app out there. One feature shoutout: giving an email address to send email newsletters to, so those can be read where they belong, with other written publications.
  3. CSS Pro
    Nice little browser extension that gives you a bunch of designer-y tools on any website for screwing around with the site immediately. It‚Äôs great for playing around and prototyping. But my favorite is that in one click you can sent just a selected element and all it‚Äôs styles over to CodePen and play in code there.
  4. gradient.style
    A nicely done CSS gradient construction tool, that includes all the types of gradients that are possible unlike so many older ones. There are nice examples, nice interactive controls, and as an important bonus: a high dynamic range color picker, so you can pick colors in OKLCH and OKLAB which are fantastic for gradients and making colors pop.
  5. Elk
    I‚Äôm grateful that such an nice web client for Mastodon exists.

üîß Code, Tools & Resources

Scroll-Driven Animations Debugger: A DevTools Extension ‚Äî A new Chrome DevTools extension specifically to visualize and debug scroll-driven¬†animations.

Bramus Van Damme

unpic/placeholder: A Library for Generating Pure CSS Image Placeholders ‚Äî This is done by extracting the dominant color from an image or by server-side rendering a BlurHash value, which then is used to display a temporary image during load¬†time.

Matt Kane

qr-code: Web Component for Animatable SVG-Based QR¬†Codes ‚Äî We‚Äôre not entirely sure why you‚Äôd want to animate a QR code, but the effects are pretty neat. You can try out the demo¬†here.

Jason Dreyzehner

React Authentication ‚Äî Without Complexity ‚Äî Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Read the docs¬†now.

Userfront sponsor

CSS Loaders: A Collection of 500+ Loading Animations ‚Äî This is a huge collection of animated single-element CSS-only loaders. You‚Äôre bound to find one that suits your project¬†here.

Temani Afif

BlendIcons: 140K+ Free Icons in Various Categories and Styles ‚Äî A simple UI lets you search via keyword and you can filter by icon styles (bold, filled, etc.). Each icon is available in different formats including SVG, PNG, JSX, CSS, HTML, Base64, etc.

Blendicons

Crop Video: Online Tool to Quickly Crop a Video File ‚Äî From Adobe Express, this tool gives you pre-built crop settings for landscape, portrait (i.e. for TikTok), square, or just do it¬†freeform.

Adobe Express

React Plock: A 1KB Masonry Grid Component ‚Äî TypeScript-ready and it‚Äôs easy to customize the grid columns and rows for responsive layouts in the style of¬†Unsplash,¬†say.

Renato Pozzi

Run Lighthouse on PageSpeed Insights Against a Set of URLs ‚Äî You'll need Node.js, but this will let you see which of the sites you supply is fastest. In other words, something like ‚ÄúAmazing Race‚Äù for¬†websites?

Zach Leatherman
